div.p: Greetings. I am compelled by the request of those who do not heed my advice to trouble you, venerable brother. A certain good man from Milan has been thrown into prison because he spoke too freely against the impiety of the papacy. He is indeed a Burgundian, but he has long lived in this city and conducts business in Italy.

Our senate was indeed prepared to intercede on his behalf; but because their letters would have been held in derision, they refrained. I gave advice, which his friends rejected; for they thought that if the four Swiss cities, which profess the pure doctrine of the gospel, interceded for him, the Milanese would hardly dare to do anything. Yet I fear that the authority of your people in this matter will also be slight and of almost no consequence. However, since the cause itself deserves uncommon commendation, I ask you again and again to assist the messenger in obtaining letters with whatever faith and diligence you can. Farewell, most illustrious and honorable brother.
May the Lord guide you with His spirit, sustain you with strength, and keep you safe! Geneva, 9th of September, 1562. Yours, Johannes Calvin.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the church in Zurich, brother and esteemed colleague.
